metadata.title: Social determinants of COVID-19 mortality at the county level 1

abstract.text: Objective: To assess the associations between COVID-19 mortality and 11 immigrant and farm worker population at the county level. 12

We used publicly accessible datasets to build a series of spatial 13 autoregressive models assessing county level associations between COVID-19 14 mortality and (1) Percentage of Non-English speaking households, (2) 15

body_text.text: A novel coronavirus responsible for COVID-19 respiratory disease is causing a 2 global pandemic which has already resulted in over 3 million cases and 240,000 3 deaths since early January 1 . The United States currently has more cases than 4 any other nation in the world, with just over 1 million cases and 61,000 deaths as 5 of May 1, 2020 1 . Preliminary data indicates that existing health inequities in the 6 United States are likely linked to COVID-19 morbidity and mortality 2 . 7 8 Methods 9

We built a series of spatial autoregressive models to assess county-level 10 associations between COVID-19 mortality and: (1) Percentage of Non-English 11 speaking households (defined as households in which no one 14 years or older 12 reports speaking English at least "very well"), (2) percentage of individuals 13 engaged in hired farm work 3 in the county as of 2018, (3) percentage of 14 In addition to hypothesized predictors, we adjusted our models to account for the 29 stage of the local epidemic by including a variable for the number of days since a 30 county reported its first case of COVID-19, and the number of days between the 31 . The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 8, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.05.03.20089698 doi: medRxiv preprint 100 th case in a state and the declaration of a state-wide shelter in place (SIP) 32 order. Arkansas, Iowa, Nebraska, North Dakota, and Wyoming were assigned a 33 '0', denoting that they had not yet implemented an SIP order at the time of these 34 analyses. 35

We first built a series of simple linear regression models to assess the bivariate 37 association between number of deaths within a county and our hypothesized 38 predictors, adjusting for days since 1st case and SIP order. We then constructed 39 a spatial contiguity matrix, and checked the assumption that residuals were 40 distributed spatially using a Moran's I test. The negative association we found between insured status and mortality is a 99 point of concern. The CDC has noted higher than expected numbers of death 100 across the United States throughout April in recent months, suggesting that 101 COVID-19 mortality is potentially higher than what has thus far been captured by 102 state and county level surveillance 7 . It is possible that this association represents 103 a gap in testing and linkage to care among the uninsured, and/or a gap in 104 ascertaining deaths due to COVID-19 among uninsured individuals. FIGREF0.text: built three separate spatial autoregressive models to assess the 43 association between number of deaths and our hypothesized social 44 determinants, adjusting for potential confounders, and fitted the model with a 45 spatial lag of the dependent variable based on our contiguity matrix. Our first 46 model assessed relationships across all counties. We then stratified our analyses 47 by population density to model (1) counties with population greater than 1000 48 individuals per square mile, and (2) a non-urban model with population density 49 less than or equal to 1000 individuals per square mile. 50 51 Results 52 This analysis encompassed 2,743 counties across all 50 states. As of April 26, 53 2020, the number of deaths reported in the NY Times aggregated dataset ranged 54 from 0 to 11,648 per county, with a median of 0 an interquartile range (IQR) of 0-55 3 1 . We classified 114 counties as urban and 2629 counties as non-urban. Deaths 56 in urban counties ranged from 0 -11648, with a median of 73 and IQR = 25-291. 57 Deaths in rural counties ranged from 0-410 with a median of 0 and IQR = 0-2. 58 1 Within this dataset, the 5 boroughs/counties of New York are treated as a single entity. We have done the same in these analyses, assigning all 5 counties the values associated with New York County. adjusted models, the percentage of residents living in poverty and 64 residents over the age of 65, and the number of individuals per square mile were 65 all independently and significantly associated with additional COVID19 mortality. 66 Each percentage point increase in poverty was associated with 2.2 additional 67 deaths across all counties (p < 0.001), and each increase in the percentage of 68 residents over the age of 65 was associated with 2.3 additional COVID19 deaths 69 (p = 0.045). Density was significantly associated with higher levels of mortality 70 across all counties, with each additional person per square mile correlating to 1counties (n=114), only population density was significantly associated 74 with COVID19 mortality (b = 0.21, p <0.001). However, in non-urban counties, all 75 hypothesized social determinants were statistically significantly associated with 76 an increase in mortality. The percentage of individuals employed in farm work, 77 percentage of non-English speaking households, and percentage of individuals 78living in poverty were all independently and significantly associated with higher 79 mortality, as was increased density and more residents over the age of 65 (see80 table 1). However, contrary to our hypotheses, percentage of uninsured 81 individuals was associated with lower reported COVID19 mortality (b = cannot draw conclusions about individual risk profiles, our findings 86 do suggest that that farm work may create unique risk factors, and that 87 farmworkers may require additional protections, such as personal protective 88 equipment and/or targeted outreach. Immigrants provide approximately 75% seek healthcare, or their ability to request additional protections from an 93 employer if they worry doing so could result in their own deportation or that of a 94 family member 5 . Farm labor is considered essential work, but there are reports

FIGREF1.text: 19 mortality appears to be statistically significantly associated with social 108 determinants of health at the county level, and these relationships may be more 109 pronounced in non-urban counties. Individuals who do not speak English, 110 individuals engaged in farm work, and individuals living in poverty may be at 111 heightened risk for COVID-19 mortality in non-urban counties.

TABREF0.text: uninsured individuals under the age of 65, (3) percentage of individuals living at 15 or below the poverty line, (4) percentage of residents age 65 or older, and (5) 16 county density, measured as number of residents per square mile. 17 18 COVID-19 mortality data was sourced from county public health agencies, 19 aggregated and made publicly available by the New York Times 4 . The proportion 20 of households with limited English speaking ability was drawn from the American 21 Community Survey's (ACS) 2014 5-year estimate, percentages of individuals 22 living below poverty and over the age of 65 were from 2017 ACS data, and 23 percentage of farmworkers was taken from the US Bureau of Economic Analysis. 24 Percent uninsured was based on the US Census Small Area Health Insurance 25
